titleStmt.title: [We need somebody or]
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: The notes on the verso of the second leaf suggest that the paper on which this manuscript is written came from the Attorney General's office, in which Whitman worked between 1865 and 1873.

The verso of the second manuscript leaf contains notes, written in pencil in an unknown hand, about legal procedings involving a shipment of cotton bound from the Confederate States for Havana in 1863. The entire page is marked with a vertical line in ink that resembles that in which Whitman's notes are written.
The following are responsible for particular readings or for changes to this file, as noted: Janel Cayer Brett Barney Vanessa Steinroetter Ashley Lawson

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: On the needs of American literature
bibl.orgName: Special Collections and University Archives, Rutgers University Libraries, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

body.p:
We need someth somebody or something, whose utterance
is were
like that w of an old Hebrew prophet's, only substituting rapt Literature instead of the rapt religion—and the
spirit amount
of
which should be: it that utterance crying aloud:
"Hear, O People! O poets & writers! you ye have
supposed made
your of literature as an accompaniment, an adjunct, as of the
the same as the
upholstery of your parlors, or the confections of your tables. Ye have made a mere ornaments, a prettiness.
You Ye
have feebly followed & feebly multiplied the models of other lands. & put Yet Ye are in the midst of idols, of clay, silver & brass. I come to call you to the truth. knowledge of the Living God, in writings. Its liter Its own literature, to a Nation, is the first of all things. Even

its Religion appears only through its Literature, & as a part of it. Know ye, Ye may have all other things, possessions, but without your own
grand Soul's
Literature, ye are as but little better than in trading, prosperous beasts. Aping but others, ye are but intelligent apes. Until ye prove title by productions, remain subordinate, & cease those that perpetual windy bragging. Far, far above alse all else, in a nation, & making all its men to move as gods, behold in a
nation race ,
its original own poets
the
bards, orators, & authors, born of the spirit & body of that
race. nation. "

Its Literature, is when it comes, is to be the most serious, most subtle, most solid part of America, & making
the its most it its conflicting elements homomogeneous & its the States a Nation, &
constituent; not pin to be a Literature pinned on its breast for a breastpin, or worn in the ears for ear‑rings.
